{{Infobox person | name = Abd-ru-shin/Abdruschin | image = Abdruschin.JPG | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Oskar Ernst Bernhardt | birth_date = {{Birth date|1875|04|18|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bischofswerda]], [[Kingdom of Saxony]], [[German Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1941|12|06|1875|04|18|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Ore Mountains (Central Europe)|Kipsdorf, Ore Mountains]], Germany | nationality = German | other_names = '''Abd-ru-shin''', '''Abdruschin''' | occupation = Author | known_for = ''[[In the Light of Truth: The Grail Message]]'' | website = [http://grail-message.com/abd-ru-shin/ Abd-ru-shin]}}
'''Oskar Ernst Bernhardt''', also known as '''Abd-ru-shin''' or '''Abdruschin''' (18 April 1875, [[Bischofswerda]], [[Kingdom of Saxony]], [[German Empire]] – 6 December 1941, [[Ore Mountains (Central Europe)|Kipsdorf, Ore Mountains]], Germany), is best known as the author of the ''[[In the Light of Truth: The Grail Message]]''.<ref>[http://www.grailmessage.com In the Light of Truth: The Grail Message]- Edition in three volumes</ref>
<!--Abd-ru-shin means "Son of Light" in the [[Persian language]].<ref>{{cite book|author-first=Massimo|author-last=Introvigne|author-link=Massimo Introvigne|editor-link=Wouter Hanegraaff|editor-last=Hanegraaff|editor-first=Wouter J.|year=2006|title=Dictionary of Gnosis and Western Esotericism|chapter=Grail Traditions in Western Esotericism|place=Leiden / Boston|publisher=Brill|pages=436–438, 1183}}</ref>--> After a brief commercial training Oskar Ernst Bernhardt began his literary activity while still a young man. This often led him to foreign countries. In 1915 he was interned in [[England]]. Released in 1919, he first went to [[Dresden]], later to [[Bavaria]] and in 1923 began to write the first lectures of the Grail Message.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://grailadministrationnigeria.org/content/author|title=The Author {{!}} Grail Administration Nigeria|website=grailadministrationnigeria.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref>
In 1928 he settled in Vomperberg, [[state of Tyrol|Tyrol]]. There he wrote [[Grail Message|"In the Light of Truth: The Grail Message]]". He was labeled a "dangerous" element by the Nazi authorities and exiled from [[Austria]] in 1938.
== The Messiah ==
He claimed to be the [[Messiah]].<ref name="Wilson1975"> {{cite book |last1=Wilson |first1=Bryan R.|author-link1=Bryan R. Wilson |year=1975 |title=The Noble Savages: The Primitive Origins of Charisma and Its Contemporary Survival |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kQE1mAKwUMUC&pg=PA114 |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |page=114 |isbn=978-0-520-02815-9 |quote=... but their prominence and relative success when compared with such figures as Louwrens van Voorthuizen (Lou) in Holland, Georges Roux in France, and Oskar Ernst Bernhardt in Germany and Austria, all of whom claimed to be the messiah—is striking. }}</ref><ref name="ClarkeClarke2004"> {{cite book |last1=Introvigne |first1=Massimo |author-link1=Massimo Introvigne |date=1 March 2004 |chapter=Grail Movement |editor1-last=Clarke |editor1-first=Peter |editor1-link=Peter Clarke (historian) |title=Encyclopedia of New Religious Movements |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DouBAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA244 |page=244 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-134-49970-0 |quote=A complicated esoteric work, which includes a history of the universe partially derived from the Theosophical Society (see Theosophy), and hinting at Berhnardt’s own messianic role, it found interested readers within the esoteric milieu (see Esoteric Movements). }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vojtisek |first1=Zdenek |date=February 2006 |title=Millennial Expectations in the Grail Movement |url=http://www.zvojtisek.cz/dokumenty/clanky/millennial_expectations.pdf |journal=Nova Religio: The Journal of Alternative and Emergent Religions |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=61–79|issn=1541-8480 |doi=10.1525/nr.2006.9.3.061 |quote=In order to calm the public and hide his messianic claims, in 1937 Bernhardt ordered that the “Conclusion” be cut out of all unsold In the Light of Truth books. ... Four lectures and the “Conclusion” published in 1931 are omitted in the authorized postwar version. The reason for dropping three of the lectures is probably the same as the reason for omitting the “Conclusion” in 1937: they were too explicit in pointing to Bernhardt (Abd-ru-shin) as the Messiah. Of the omitted lectures, the fourth was probably unacceptable after the war due to ideas that might be considered racist.<sup>28</sup> }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Kürti |first=László |date=April 2001 |title=Psychic Phenomena, Neoshamanism, and the Cultic Milieu in Hungary |journal=Nova Religio: The Journal of Alternative and Emergent Religions |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=322–350 |doi=10.1525/nr.2001.4.2.322 |quote=Cultic milieu books, long familiar to Westerners, are being translated into Hungarian and sold in legitimate bookstores. The latest examples are Akashic Records by Victor Charon and The Message of the Grail by Abd-Ru-Shin [Oskar Ernst Bernhardt (1875-1941)]. Both are fashionable books involving esoteric worldviews with messianic claims, and both are widely distributed on the Hungarian publishing market. }}</ref><ref>« Etwa seit 1923 spürte O. E. Bernhardt seinen besonderen religiösen Auftrag. Er betrachtete sich selbst als Gottesgesandten und als den verheißenen "Menschensohn", der das unvollkommene Werk des "Gottessohnes" Jesus Christus vollenden sollte. 1924 ließ er sich scheiden und begann wenig später mit der Veröffentlichung von Abhandlungen in der von ihm herausgegebenen Zeitschrift "Gralsblätter". Dabei nannte er sich "Abd-ru-shin". » (Plagge 2003: 120-122).</ref><ref>« '''''Abd-ru-shin''''' (= Oskar Ernst Bernhardt; 1875-1941), ein Deutscher, sah das Werk Jesu Christi als gescheitert an und verkündigte sich selbst als den „wahren Christus“, welcher der Menschheit die rettende „Gralsbotschaft“ übermittelt. » (Gassmann 1999).</ref><ref>« Das dreibändige 1926 erschiene Werk ''Im Lichte der Wahrheit – Gralsbotschaft von Abd-ru-shin'' ist eine Sammlung von 168 Vorträgen und enthält die Hauptgedanken des Mannes, der sich als „Menschensohn“<sup>82</sup> verstand und in einer Pyramide auf dem Tiroler Vomperberg begraben ließ. » Diemling (2012: 153).</ref> By his own admission, he was described in leading newspapers as the Messiah of the Tyrol and the Prophet of Vomperberg.<ref name="Abd-ru-shin1995">{{cite book |author=Abd-ru-shin |date=1 June 1995 |chapter=Chapter 7: The Distorted Tool |title=In the Light of Truth: The Grail Message |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2NfdoX_rYk0C&pg=PA754 |volume=III |page=754 |publisher=[[Grail Foundation Press]] |isbn=978-1-57461-006-2 }}</ref>
The Grail Movement maintains discretion in respect to his role as Messiah/Son of Man.<ref name="CardiniIntrovigne1998"> {{cite book |author-last1=Cardini |author-first1=Franco |author-last2=Introvigne |author-first2=Massimo |author-last3=Montesano |author-first3=Marina |date=1 January 1998 |title=Il Santo Graal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZlosPTOzdj8C&pg=PA142 |language=Italian |page=142 |publisher=[[Giunti Editore]] |isbn=978-88-09-21274-9 |quote=Lo stesso Abd-Ru-Shin ha un ruolo messianico, su cui il movimento preferisce mantenere oggi una certa discrezione pubblica (anche se per i fedeli Abd-Ru-Shin altri non è che l’incarnazione di Parsifal). }}</ref>
==Life, publishing, legacy==
{{unreferenced section|date=May 2015}}
Bernhardt was born in Bischofswerda, Germany, trained in business, and successfully established himself in Dresden. He traveled and wrote travel books, stories, and plays. He resided in New York and London. He was in London when World War I broke out and in 1914 he was interned on the [[Isle of Man]].
This seclusion gave him time to reflect, question, and deepen his understanding. He was released in the Spring of 1919 and returned to Germany. He began to write ''In the Light of Truth: The Grail Message'' in 1923 and completed it in 1931 under the pen name Abd-ru-shin.
In 1928 he settled in Austria, Tyrol on a mountain plateau called Vomperberg. Here he continued writing ''The Grail Message''. The Nazis came to power in 1938, ending his work there. He was arrested and exiled to Kipsdorf in the Erzgebirge. He was forbidden any further writing. He died while in Gestapo custody.
==Legacy== After the war, his family returned to Vomperberg and carried on his work. Other writings by Abd-ru-shin published by Grail Foundation Press include ''The Ten Commandments of God and The Lord's Prayer'', ''Questions and Answers'', and ''Prayers''.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}

{{distinguish|Effusion}} [[Image:Child baptism with water.jpg|thumb|right|266px|Affusion of the [[infant]]]] '''Affusion''' ([[Latin|la.]] ''affusio'') is a method of [[baptism]] where water is poured on the head of the person being baptized. The word "affusion" comes from the Latin ''affusio'', meaning "to pour on".[http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=Affusion "Affusion"] ''Dictionary.com'' Affusion is one of four methods of baptism used by Christians, which also include total [[submersion baptism]], partial [[immersion baptism]], and [[aspersion]] or sprinkling."There are four principal methods of baptizing: (1) submersion (or total immersion) ; (2) immersion, when the head is dipped with or without the candidate standing in the water; (3) affusion, when water is poured over the head and (4) …" (John Gordon Davies, ''The Architectural Setting of Baptism''. Barrie and Rockliff 1962. p. 23)."The four principal modes are: 1. ''Submersion''; or total immersion, where the candidate goes briefly but entirely below the water, on the model of those baptised by John in the River Jordan; 2. ''Immersion''; where the head, as the prime seat of Man's rational and spiritual being, is in some way submerged, with or without the candidate having to stand in the same container of water; 3. ''Affusion''; …" ([https://books.google.com/books?id=BgkQIcRgNk0C&pg=PA204&dq=baptism+submersion+immersion+affusion&hl=en&ei=F5bITJyiN43vsgb67oHHBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=baptism%20submersion%20immersion%20affusion&f=false Charles Thomas, ''Christianity in Roman Britain to A.D. 500'']. University of California Press 1981 {{ISBN|0-520-04392-8}}. p, 204"In the early Church baptism was by one of four methods: complete submersion of the entire body, immersion of the head, affusion or pouring, or aspersion or sprinkling" ([https://books.google.com/books?id=bekUBTND4q4C&pg=PA113&dq=baptism+submersion+immersion+affusion&hl=en&ei=F5bITJyiN43vsgb67oHHBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=baptism%20submersion%20immersion%20affusion&f=false Steven J. Schloeder, ''Architecture in Communion'']. Ignatius Press 1998 {{ISBN|0-89870-631-9}}. p. 113)."There have been four different modes of conferring baptism throughout history: (1) ''submersion'', also called ''dipping'', in which the candidate is completely submerged under the baptismal waters; (2) ''immersion'', in which the candidate stands or kneels in rather shallow water, and the water is either poured over the head of the candidate or the candidate's head itself is pushed partially into the water; (3) ''affusion'', in which water is poured over the head of the candidate; and (4) ''aspersion'' …" ([https://books.google.com/books?id=693VAAAAMAAJ&q=baptism+submersion+immersion+affusion&dq=baptism+submersion+immersion+affusion&hl=en&ei=DKTITM7vIdCOswbBt_WBCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA S. Anita Stauffer, ''On Baptismal Fonts: Ancient and Modern''. Grove Books 1994, pp. 9-10).] Christian denominations which baptize by affusion do not deny the legitimacy of baptizing by submersion or immersion; rather, they consider that affusion is a sufficient, if not necessarily preferable, method of baptism. Affusion and aspersion tend to be practiced by [[Christian denomination]]s that also practice [[infant baptism]]. This may be due to the practical difficulties of totally immersing an infant underwater. However, [[Eastern Orthodox]] and some [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholics]] practice infant immersion. [[Amish]], [[Old Order Mennonites]], and [[Conservative Mennonites]] still practice baptism by pouring. ==History of affusion== Affusion became the standard practice in the western church around the 10th century,[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9013238 "Baptistery"], ''Encyclopædia Britannica'', 2007. Retrieved March 7, 2007. but was in use much earlier. The earliest explicit reference to baptism by affusion occurs in the [[Didache]] (c. AD 100), the seventh chapter of which gives instructions on how to baptize, which include affusion:
…But if you have no living water, baptize into other water; and if you cannot do so in cold water, do so in warm. But if you have neither, '''pour out''' water three times upon the head into the name of Father and Son and Holy Spirit. (Emphasis added)[http://www.earlychristianwritings.com/text/didache-roberts.html "Didache"] in ''The Ante-Nicene Fathers: Translations of the Writings of the Fathers down to A.D. 325''. vol. 1. Roberts, Alexander; Donaldson, James; and Coxe, A. Cleveland, Eds. (Grand Rapids: Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company), 1951 (original pub. in U.S. 1885).
This text implies that early Christians saw affusion as a viable alternative to immersion when no living water (i.e. running water like a river or spring) or cold water is available. Acts of various martyrs show that many were baptized in prison, while awaiting martyrdom; immersion would have been impossible. The most common use, however, was for ill or dying people who could not rise from their beds. It was consequently known as "baptism of the sick". Receiving this baptism was regarded as a bar to [[Holy Orders]], but this sprang from the person's having put off baptism until the last moment—a practice that in the fourth century became common, with people enrolling as [[catechumen]]s but not being baptized for years or decades. While the practice was decried at the time, the intent of the criticism was not to encourage baptism by immersion, but to refrain from delaying baptism. ==Affusion and the Bible== In the [[New Testament]] book of [[Acts of the Apostles|Acts]], the [[baptism of the Holy Spirit]] is sometimes described, as a “pouring out” of the [[Holy Spirit]] ([http://bible.gospelcom.net/bible?acts+2:17-18,33;acts+10:45 Acts 2:17,18,33; Acts 10:45]). [[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]], the author of [[Acts of the Apostles|Acts]], uses the word "baptism" to describe a "pouring," which seems to indicate that the word "baptism" can refer to pouring and not just dipping or immersing. It may also indicate that [[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]]’s concept of baptism includes, or allows for, [[baptism]] by pouring. For instance, on [[Pentecost]], the [[disciple (Christianity)|disciples]] were baptized with the [[Holy Spirit]] by having the Spirit “poured out” on them from heaven not by being dipped in the [[Holy Spirit]] until they were completely immersed. Submersionists say that passages like these do not directly speak to the issue of water baptism because they are, strictly speaking, about baptism with the [[Holy Spirit]]. Affusionists think they indirectly apply to water baptism, though, by telling us something about the general ''concept'' of baptism, regardless of whether the medium of baptism is water or Spirit. Affusionists see more evidence that [[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]]’s concept of baptism includes pouring by noting an additional possible connection between water baptism and Holy Spirit baptism. In [[Acts 10]], Peter is “astonished that the gift of the Holy Spirit had been poured out even on the Gentiles” ([http://bible.gospelcom.net/bible?Acts+10:45 Acts 10:45]). Peter responds by saying, “Can anyone keep these people from being baptized with water? They have received the Holy Spirit just as we have" ([http://bible.gospelcom.net/bible?Acts+10:47 Acts 10:47]). Affusionists read Peter to be saying "by having the Spirit poured out on them, these people already have been baptized with the Spirit, so why not actually baptize them with water." They understand Peter’s words to imply that water baptism is a symbolic picture of the Holy Spirit baptism. If this is right, affusionists contend, then water baptism should be, or, at least, can be, by pouring, because the baptism with the Holy Spirit of which it is a picture occurs by pouring. Also noteworthy to affusionists is that, in [http://bible.gospelcom.net/bible?Luke+11:38 Luke 11:38], the word ''ἐβαπτίσθη'' [''ebaptisthē''][http://biblehub.com/greek/ebaptisthe__907.htm ''ebaptisthē''] is used in the Greek and ''baptizatus''[http://www.latin-dictionary.net/definition/6105/baptizo-baptizare-baptizavi-baptizatus ''baptizatus''] is used in the Latin.[http://biblehub.com/interlinear/luke/11-38.htm Luke 11:38 Greek Interlinear][http://newadvent.org/bible/luk011.htm New Advent: Luke 11] Both words are used, in other passages, to mean baptism. But in that verse of Luke, the "washing" referred to is partial, like affusion. ==See also== {{Portal|Christianity}} *[[Aspersion]] *[[Baptism]] *[[Believer's baptism]] *[[Baptism of desire]] *[[Baptism of Jesus]] *[[Baptism with the Holy Spirit]] *[[Christianity]] *[[Conditional baptism]] *[[Immersion baptism]] *[[Infant baptism]] *[[John the Baptist]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02258b.htm ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' "Baptism"] [[Category:Baptism]] [[Category:Water and religion]] [[Category:Christian terminology]]

{{Infobox religious biography |name = Anathapindika |image = Jetvan bharhut.JPG |caption = Anathapindika covers Jetavana with coins ([[Bharhut]], [[Brahmi]] text: jetavana ananthapindiko deti kotisanthatena keta |birth name = |alias = Sudatta |dharma name = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = |religion = [[Buddhism]] |school = |lineage = |title = Chief Lay Disciple |location = |education = |profession = Merchant |teacher = [[Gautama Buddha]] |reincarnation of = |predecessor = |successor = |students = |spouse = |partner = |children = |website = }} '''Anathapindika''' ({{lang-pi|Anāthapiṇḍika}}; {{lang-sa|Anāthapiṇḍada}}) was a wealthy merchant and banker, believed to have been the wealthiest merchant in [[Savatthi]] in the time of [[Gautama Buddha]]. Born '''Sudatta''', he received the nickname ''Anathapindika'', literally "one who gives alms to the poor", due to his reputation of loving to give to those in need. Anathapindika was the chief male lay disciple and the greatest [[Patronage|patron]] of Gautama Buddha along with his female counterpart [[Visakha]]. Anathapindika is known as the male lay disciple of the Buddha who was foremost in generosity. Anathapindika is frequently referred to as Anathapindika-''setthi'' (''[[śreṣṭhī|setthi]]'' meaning "wealthy person" or "millionaire"), and is sometimes referred to as Mahā Anāthapindika to distinguish him from Cūla Anāthapindika, another disciple of the Buddha.
== Background == In Buddhist belief, when a fully enlightened [[Buddha (title)|Buddha]] arrives in the world, he always has a set of chief disciples that fulfill different roles. On top of the pair of chief [[Arahant]] disciples such as Gautama Buddha's chief male disciples [[Sariputta]] and [[Moggallana]], and his chief female disciples [[Khema]] and [[Uppalavanna]], all Buddhas have a set of chief lay disciples as well. Gautama Buddha's chief male lay disciple and patron was Anathapindika, with his chief female lay disciple and patron being [[Visakha]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.myanmarnet.net/nibbana/gotama/gcobv12.htm#24|title=The great chronicle of Buddhas|last=Lay|first=U Do|date=|website=www.myanmarnet.net|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170602031053/http://www.myanmarnet.net/nibbana/gotama/gcobv12.htm#24|archive-date=2017-06-02|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-03-17|df=}}</ref>
According to the [[Pāli Canon|Pali Canon]], in the time of [[Padumuttara Buddha|Padumattara Buddha]], a householder was inspired when Padumattara Buddha spoke of his own chief lay disciple and patron. The householder then resolved in that lifetime to become the chief lay disciple of a future Buddha himself, and did several good deeds in hopes of becoming one. His wish was fulfilled in this lifetime when he was reborn as Anathapindika and became the chief male lay disciple of Gautama Buddha.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.palikanon.com/english/pali_names/ay/anaathapindika.htm|title=Anāthapindika|website=www.palikanon.com|access-date=2018-03-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230025428/http://www.palikanon.com/english/pali_names/ay/anaathapindika.htm|archive-date=2017-12-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
==Biography ==
=== Early Life and Family === Anathapindika was born with the given name Sudatta, and was the son of a wealthy merchant named Sumana. When Sudatta grew up, he married a woman named Puññalakkhanā, the sister of a wealthy merchant in [[Rajagaha|Rājagaha]]. Sudatta was known for his generosity even before his conversion to Buddhism, and was known to the public by the nickname "Anathapindika", or "one who gives alms to the poor", due to his love for giving. Anathapindika had one son, Kāla, and three daughters, Mahā-Subhaddā, Cūla-Subhaddā and Sumanā. His daughter-in-law was Sujātā, the youngest sister of his female counterpart, [[Visakha]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":022"/>
=== Meeting the Buddha === The [[Pāli Canon|Pali Canon]] describes Anathapindika's first encounter with the Buddha as being in Rājagaha. While on business, Anathapindika went to visit his brother-in-law, who was already a follower of the Buddha. When he arrived at this brother-in-law's house, he noticed that the household was preparing for an elaborate feast, and mistook it as preparation for a wedding or a visit from the king.<ref name=":022">{{Cite web|url=http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/hecker/wheel334.html|title=Anathapindika: The Great Benefactor|website=www.accesstoinsight.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171008080100/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/hecker/wheel334.html|archive-date=2017-10-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> When Anathapindika asked about the preparations, his brother-in-law explained that they were preparing for a visit from the Buddha (the Enlightened One) and his monks. Upon hearing this, Anathapindika became overjoyed, exclaiming "You mean that a fully enlightened being had arisen in the world?", and immediately resolved to go meet him.<ref name=":02">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IStatqlilL8C&pg=PA64&dq=Anathapindika&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjRk7S1id_WAhXLiVQKHW2sBXQQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=Anathapindika&f=false|title=The Buddha and His Disciples|last=Dhammika|first=Shravasti|date=2005-12-01|publisher=Buddhist Publication Society|isbn=9789552402807|language=en}}</ref>
The following day Anathapindika arose early to meet the Buddha, but realized it was still dark. He still continued however, after a friendly [[Yaksha|yakka]] whispered in his ear and urged him to continue. Anathapindika eventually reached a figure which called him "Sudatta" and asked him to come forward. Surprised to hear his birth name, which was not known to the public, he concluded it could only be the Buddha, and went forward. The Buddha then had a discussion with him and expounded the [[Four Noble Truths]], afterwards Anathapindika achieved the state of [[Sotāpanna|Sotapanna]], a stage of [[Four stages of enlightenment|enlightenment]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://obo.genaud.net/backmatter/appendixes/personalities/anathapindiko.htm|title=Anathapindiko|website=obo.genaud.net|language=en|access-date=2017-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171008030508/http://obo.genaud.net/backmatter/appendixes/personalities/anathapindiko.htm|archive-date=2017-10-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref name=":022"/><ref name=":02"/>[[File:Anathapindika's great act of charity.jpg|thumb|Anathapindika's great act of charity|alt=]] === Building Jetavana Monastery === Following Anathapindika's first encounter with the Buddha, he requested to offer him a meal, which the Buddha accepted, and then asked to build a temple for him and his monks in his hometown of Savatthi, to which the Buddha agreed.<ref name=":022"/>
Shortly after, Anathapindika went back to Savatthi to search for a place to build the monastery. Looking for a place that was both accessible to followers and peacefully secluded, he came across a park belonging to Prince Jeta, the son of [[Pasenadi|King Pasenadi]] of [[Kosala]]. Anathapindika offered to buy the park from the prince but the prince refused, after Anathapindika persisted, the prince joking said he will sell him the park if he covers it with gold coins, to which Anathapindika agreed.<ref name=":02" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/bud/btg/btg26.htm|title=Jetavana, The Vihara|website=www.sacred-texts.com|access-date=2017-10-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909142638/http://www.sacred-texts.com/bud/btg/btg26.htm|archive-date=2017-09-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
Anathapindika later came back with wagons full of gold pieces to cover the park with. When Prince Jeta stated he was merely joking, Anathapindika and the prince went to arbitrators who concluded that Prince Jeta had to sell the park at the agreed price. After seeing Anathapindika's resolve, Prince Jeta offered to build a wall and gate for the monastery. Afterwards, Anathapindika spent several million more gold pieces building the temple and its furnishings, in what would come to be known as the [[Jetavana|Jetavana Monastery]], also often referred to in Buddhist scriptures as "Anathapindika's Monastery".<ref name=":022" /><ref name=":02" />
=== Chief Lay Disciple === The Buddha designated Anathapindika as his chief lay disciple, along with [[Visakha]]. He is considered to be the male Buddhist lay disciple who was foremost in both generosity and character. Throughout his life, Anathapindika received hundreds of monks at his house for alms daily and regularly sent food, medicine and supplies to the monastery. The temple was also regularly maintained by Anathapindika's servants.<ref name=":022" />
Whenever the Buddha was in [[Savatthi]], Anathapindika would visit him twice a day. After first meeting the Buddha, Anathapindika committed to following the teachings and strictly observing the [[Five Precepts|five precepts]], as well as encouraged his family, friends, employees, and everybody around him to do the same.<ref name=":022" /> Anathapindika was also well versed in the [[Dharma (Buddhism)|Dhamma]], and an excellent debater. Buddhist scriptures describe a time when he visited a temple of another religious tradition and a debate ensues, with Anathapindika skillfully defeating the followers of the other religious tradition.<ref name=":022" /><ref name=":3" />
Anathapindika and Visakha were not only the greatest donors to Gautama Buddha but also his primary aides when dealing with the general public. The Buddha frequently turned to one of the two chief lay disciples whenever there needed to be something arranged with the lay community.<ref name=":022" />
=== Encounter with the Earth Spirit === [[File:Jetavana - Buildings, Shravasti (9237067203).jpg|thumb|Scene of some remains at [[Jetavana|Jetavana Monastery]].]]Even the wealthy Anathapindika's wealth was not limitless. At one time, the wealthy banker lost a significant amount of his fortune in a flash flood, which washed away large amounts of his gold, and was reduced to poverty due to his love of giving as well as due to lending out large amounts to his friends. Despite this, Anathapindika continued his patronage and support of Buddhism, although more modestly. It is said he later returned to his wealthy status, however, due to the help of a redemptive [[Deva (Buddhism)|''deva'']], or spirit.<ref name=":02"/><ref name=":022"/>
Based on accounts from the Buddhist scriptures, there was a ''deva'' living in Anathapindika's house at the time. According to the [[31 planes of existence|laws of his realm]], the ''deva'' had to leave his abode whenever the Buddha or a monk was in the house, as a form of respect. Annoyed by this, the ''deva'' appeared before Anathapindika and suggested he preserve his treasure and stop his patronage of Buddhism since he was no longer wealthy. Appalled by this suggestion, Anathapindika explained that the only treasures he knew of were the [[Three Jewels]]; the Buddha, the [[Dharma (Buddhism)|Dhamma]], and the [[Sangha]], and that he would continue to support Buddhism so long as he had something to give. Anathapindika then ordered the ''deva'' to leave his house, stating that enemies of the Buddha were not welcome, forcing the ''deva'' to find a new place to live. The homeless ''deva'' went to several authorities, eventually reaching [[Śakra (Buddhism)|Sakka]], the king of the ''devas'' in [[Trāyastriṃśa]], who suggested he must atone by retrieving Anathapindika's lost gold, convincing his debtors to repay their debts, and by giving Anathapindika a buried treasure, which had no owner. This resulted in Anathapindika returning to wealth, even richer than he was before.<ref name=":02"/><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zMYViaXor6cC&pg=PA89&dq=Anathapindika&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjn37jJ5N_WAhXlrlQKHVcJBMcQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=Anathapindika&f=false|title=Philanthropy in the World's Traditions|last=Ilchman|first=Warren Frederick|last2=Katz|first2=Stanley Nider|last3=Queen|first3=Edward L.|date=1998|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=|isbn=025333392X|location=|pages=89|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":022"/>
=== The Story of Kalakanni === The extent of Anathapindika's generosity was not limited just to material gifts. One famous story described in the Buddhist scriptures is the story of Kalakanni. Kalakanni (whose name means "unlucky bird")<ref name=":022"/> was a childhood friend of Anathapindika who was impoverished. When Kalakanni asked Anathapindika for aid, the ''setthi'' offered him a job at his house. This decision was met with backlash from Anathapindika's household, due to Kalakanni's low status and the superstition at the time of Kalakanni's name being a bad omen. Anathapindika ignored this superstition and his status however, and granted his friend a job. This eventually worked in the favor of the household however, when a group of thieves attempted to rob Anathapindika while he was away on a business trip. When the vigilant Kalakanni noticed the thieves, he started making loud noises, convincing the thieves that the household was full and causing them to leave.<ref name=":022" />
=== Death === When Anathapindika grew ill later in life he was visited by [[Sariputta]] and [[Ananda]], two of the Buddha's principle disciples. Sariputta delivered a sermon, recommending Anathapindika focus on freeing his mind from clinging and to reflect on the impermanence of existence. The ''setthi'' later proclaimed this sermon to have been the most profound sermon he has ever heard, which Sariputta explained was because this teaching was not normally given to laypeople.<ref name=":2" /> Shortly after Sariputta and Ananda left, Anathapindika died. According to the Buddhist scriptures, Anathapindika was reborn as a [[Deva (Buddhism)|''deva'']] in [[Tushita|Tusita]] heaven after his death, where he would live as long as his female counterpart [[Visakha]], and the king of [[Tavatimsa]] heaven, [[Śakra (Buddhism)|Sakka]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/ay/anaathapindika.htm|title=Anáthapindika|website=palikanon.de|access-date=2017-12-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013172420/http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/ay/anaathapindika.htm|archive-date=2017-10-13|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/hecker/wheel334.html#part5|title=Anathapindika: The Great Benefactor|website=www.accesstoinsight.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180822145605/https://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/hecker/wheel334.html#part5|archive-date=2018-08-22|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
== Legacy == [[File:Jetavana.jpg|thumb|The remains of a section of [[Jetavana|Jetavana Monastery]].]] Anathapindika is considered to be one of the most exemplary adherents of the Buddhist virtue of generosity. Not only did he regularly provide alms and necessities to the monks at Jetavana, he hosted hundreds of monks at his residence for meals daily.<ref name=":022"/> Referring to Anathapindika, the Buddha stated that for one who was dedicated to perfecting the virtue of generosity, nothing in the world is capable of stopping him from giving. Anathapindika's love of giving, combined with some misfortune, at one point reduced the ''setthi'' to poverty. But even in times of hardship, Anathapindika was described as continuing his patronage of Buddhism, although with much more modest gifts. His wealth was eventually [[Karma in Buddhism|restored to him]] however, due to the power of the [[Merit (Buddhism)|merit]] of his generosity.<ref name=":2" />
Anathapindika's patronage had a significant impact on Buddhism. Anathapindika's hometown of [[Savatthi]] was considered to be the center of Buddhism at the time, being the location of a significant number of the Buddha's sermons. On top of that, the Buddha spent more [[Vassa|rainy seasons]] at [[Jetavana|Jetavana monastery]] than at any other temple during his lifetime.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tricycle.org/magazine/sravasti-diamond-rough/|title=Sravasti: Diamond in the Rough|last=Badiner|first=Allan Hunt|work=Tricycle: The Buddhist Review|access-date=2017-10-13|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013172527/https://tricycle.org/magazine/sravasti-diamond-rough/|archive-date=2017-10-13|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/ay/anaathapindika.htm|title=Anáthapindika|website=palikanon.de|access-date=2017-10-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013172420/http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/ay/anaathapindika.htm|archive-date=2017-10-13|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> After the building of Migāramātupāsāda monastery in Savatthi by [[Visakha]], the Buddha would alternate between Anathapindika's monastery and Visakha's monastery whenever he was staying in Savatthi.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/j/jetavana.htm|title=Jetavana|website=palikanon.de|access-date=2018-03-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318055031/http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/j/jetavana.htm|archive-date=2018-03-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/me_mu/migaramatupasada.htm|title=Migáramátupásáda|website=palikanon.de|access-date=2018-03-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318054545/http://palikanon.de/english/pali_names/me_mu/migaramatupasada.htm|archive-date=2018-03-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Anathapindika's generosity even inspired [[Pasenadi|King Pasenadi]], another follower of the Buddha, to himself start generous patronage of Buddhism.<ref name=":022"/>
Buddhist scholars George D. Bond and [[Ananda W. P. Guruge|Ananda W.P Guruge]], point to the story of Anathapindika as evidence that the Buddhist path for lay people and the rewards of generosity in Buddhism are not distinct from the path to [[Nirvana (Buddhism)|Nirvana]] that is the focus of Buddhist monastics.<ref name=":2" />
